channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Biden and Xi to meet amid economic and military tensions.
item.description: U.S. officials said the virtual summit on Monday was intended to reassure both sides that misunderstandings would not lead to unintended clashes.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden will virtually meet with President Xi Jinping of China as the two leaders confront the growing tensions between their countries.

item.title: How a Dispute Over Groceries Led to Artillery Strikes in Ukraine
item.description: In a sign of volatile East-West relations, a dispute over shopping in the Ukrainian conflict zone spiraled into fighting that sent war jitters rippling through Europe and the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the town of Hranitne, the access point for shopping for about a hundred people living in the nearby buffer zone is a footbridge crossing the Kalmius River.

item.title: Europe Toughens Rules for Unvaccinated as Fourth Covid Wave Swells
item.description: Austria took the hardest line yet on Monday, beginning a lockdown aimed exclusively at those who are not inoculated, part of a pattern to make life harder for resisters.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: An Austrian police officer checked a driver’s vaccination certificate on a smartphone on Monday during a traffic control in Graz, Austria.

item.title: U.S. Journalist Danny Fenster Is Freed From Myanmar Prison
item.description: The release was a rare positive development in the country, which has been torn by violence since a February coup.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: A New Source of Fuel in an Aging Japan: Adult Incontinence
item.description: Waste from adult diapers is growing by tens of thousands of tons a year in Japan. One town may have a solution: recycle it into fuel pellets.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: James Whitlow Delano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Health care workers from the Daisen Rehabilitation Hospital in Houki, Japan, collecting used adult diapers to be recycled into pellets.

item.title: Liverpool Explosion: Blast Is Declared a Terrorist Act
item.description: Local leaders praised the driver as a hero, saying that he may have prevented a bigger calamity. He escaped the burning vehicle and locked the doors, trapping a passenger carrying explosives inside.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Police and forensic officers on Monday outside the hospital in Liverpool where a taxi exploded a day earlier.

item.title: Afghan College Students Find a New Life, and Safety, in Iraq
item.description: Regarded as infidels by the Taliban, over 100 students from the American University in Kabul have found an unlikely refuge in the Iraqi Kurdish city of Sulaimaniya.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students relaxing in the cafeteria of the American University of Iraq in Sulaimaniya, where 109 Afghan students are now studying.

item.title: Climate Promises Made in Glasgow Now Rest With a Handful of Powerful Leaders
item.description: In Washington, Beijing, New Delhi and beyond, governments face conflicting forces — political, social and economic — that will shape their next steps in the effort to avert a climate crisis.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Solar panels in Shanxi Province in China, a country that is a major emitter of greenhouse gases that are warming the world.

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte to Run for Senate in the Philippines
item.description: Rodrigo Duterte entered the race days after his daughter announced her bid for vice president. He had previously said he would leave politics at the end of his term.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines with Sara Duterte, his daughter, in 2019.

item.title: Japan’s Economy Shrinks, but Outlook Is Brighter as Virus Ebbs
item.description: The coronavirus and supply chain issues stymied growth in the third quarter, but high vaccination rates and low numbers of virus cases point to a recovery.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: The Japanese economy has been stuck in a cycle of expansion and contraction, ebbing and flowing with the virus’s waves.

item.title: They Warned Their Names Were on a Hit List. They Were Killed.
item.description: In less than a month, assassins have killed at least eight people in the Rohingya refugee camps of Bangladesh, silencing those who have dared to speak out against the violent gangs.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kutupalong refugee camp in Bangladesh. A militant group, the Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army, claims that it has spiritual and political authority over nearly one million Rohingya refugees, and it has killed those who speak out against it.

item.title: The String of ISIS Attacks That Killed Three Generations of One Afghan Family
item.description: Over two weeks, the Rajabis suffered loss after loss as suicide attacks on Shiite mosques in two parts of the country ravaged their family.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Yaqoob Akbary and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A relative of Maisam Rajabi, a 15-year-old boy killed in a mosque bombing in Kandahar, mourns inside Bibi Fatima Mosque.

item.title: Air Route to Belarus Closed to Migrants in Bid to Halt Crisis
item.description: Hoping to stem the flow of migrants stuck on the border of Belarus and Poland, Dubai banned Iraqi and Syrian passengers from traveling to Minsk.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: A group of migrants outside a hotel in Minsk on Sunday.

item.title: Austria’s New Coronavirus Lockdown Applies Only to the Unvaccinated.
item.description: The restrictions were among the toughest of a wave of new rules in Europe, which the W.H.O. has said is “back at the epicenter of the pandemic.”
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Barbara Gindl/Agence France-Presse, via Apa/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: People waiting to get a Covid vaccination in Salzburg, Austria, on Monday, as a nationwide lockdown began for unvaccinated people.

item.title: Two Journalists in India Arrested as Media Crackdown Continues
item.description: Faced with sectarian violence in the country’s northeast, the government has responded by disputing reports on the clashes and punishing those who covered them.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Students in New Delhi last month protested the recent violence in Tripura, a state in northeast India.

item.title: Stop Using Our Haka, Maori Tribe Tells Anti-Vaccine Protesters
item.description: Ngati Toa, which owns the legal rights to the dance, said it supports Covid vaccinations as the best chance to protect a group that has suffered disproportionally from pandemics.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Anti-vaccine protesters performing a haka outside Parliament in Wellington, New Zealand, last week.

item.title: Covid Thanksgiving, Round 2
item.description: How health experts are thinking about the holidays.
item.dc:creator: Tara Parker-Pope
item.media:credit: Isadora Kosofsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thanksgiving last year in Los Angeles.

item.title: Inside the Struggle to Save Bulgaria’s Last Narrow-Gauge Railroad
item.description: The Rhodope Narrow-Gauge Railway serves remote communities in southwestern Bulgaria. Can longtime riders — and young enthusiasts — keep it running?
item.dc:creator: Jodi Hilton
item.media:description: Pomak women board the narrow-gauge train after selling their products in the town of Velingrad.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: The impact of COP26.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Shannon
item.media:description: The Ffos-y-Fran coal mine in Merthyr Tydfil, Wales. The open-air mine, which is due to close in 2022, is one of the few of its kind left in the United Kingdom.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A global climate agreement.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: John Kerry, the U.S. climate envoy, third from right, on Saturday in Glasgow with his counterparts from China and the European Union.

item.title: Taxi Explodes Outside Liverpool Hospital, Killing One
item.description: Three men in their twenties were arrested under Britain’s Terrorism Act several hours after the explosion, in which a second person was injured, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: The police in Liverpool, England, responded to reports on Sunday that a taxi had pulled up outside Liverpool Women’s Hospital and exploded, the authorities said.

item.title: Qaddafi Son to Run for President in Libya
item.description: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the former heir apparent of the deposed Libyan dictator Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, filed his candidacy papers on Sunday for the election expected next month.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Libyan High National Electoral Commission, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, front left, registered his candidacy on Sunday in Sabha, Libya. He has spent the past several years out of the public eye.

item.title: At Least 1 Dead After Quakes Strike Southern Iran
item.description: Two moderate temblors hit Hormozgan Province on Sunday afternoon, state TV reported.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Austria to Target the Unvaccinated in New Lockdown
item.description: The country, facing the biggest surge in virus cases since the pandemic started, is putting strict curbs on the movement of those without shots.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Barbara Gindl/Agence France-Presse, via Apa/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: People waiting to get a Covid vaccination in Salzburg, Austria, on Monday, as a nationwide lockdown began for unvaccinated people.

item.title: Sierra Leone Explosion Kills More and Strains Health System
item.description: Victims are still dying from injuries after a fuel tanker burst into flames last week in Sierra Leone, a country that has no burn units.
item.dc:creator: Mara Kardas-Nelson and Ruth Maclean
item.media:description: The already staggering death toll from a fuel tanker explosion in Freetown, Siera Leone, is expected to grow as victims succumb to their injuries.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Misses Remembrance Service Because of Sprained Back
item.description: The British monarch, 95, has put off multiple trips and engagements recently, and the latest cancellation has deepened anxiety about her health. She has now been out of sight since mid-October.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in October. Her withdrawal from a service on Sunday to honor Britain’s war dead was announced less than two hours before she was scheduled to appear.

item.title: Young Dissidents Call for a Day of Protest in Cuba
item.description: Young dissidents who rely on the internet to spread their ideas are calling for a protest on Monday, a bold move with little precedent in Cuba.
item.dc:creator: Ed Augustin
item.media:credit: Eliana Aponte Tobar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cubans waiting in line to buy food in Havana on Thursday. Food shortages mean that Cubans must have a numbered ticket to shop at a government supermarket.

item.title: What Is Tromethamine, or Tris? It Helps Stabilize Covid Vaccines
item.description: Also known as tris, the compound helps maintain the pH of vaccines, extending shelf life at warmer temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:description: Vials of the children’s version of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine can be stored unopened in regular refrigerators for up to 10 weeks.

item.title: The U.S. welcomes international travelers, and broadening booster eligibility: the week in Covid news.
item.dc:creator: Todd Gregory
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: A reunion at Miami International Airport on Monday. That day alone, over 200,000 international travelers arrived in the United States, according to Customs and Border Protection.

item.title: How the U.S. Hid an Airstrike That Killed Dozens of Civilians in Syria
item.description: The military never conducted an independent investigation into a 2019 bombing on the last bastion of the Islamic State, despite concerns about a secretive commando force.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Fleeing heavy bombardment in Baghuz, Syria — the Islamic State’s last holdout — on March 18, 2019.

item.title: India Wants to Send Wheat to Ease Afghan Hunger Crisis. Pakistan Has Yet to OK Transit.
item.description: Indian officials say Islamabad is dragging its feet on a request of transit for 50,000 tons of wheat to Afghanistan, where nine million people are on the brink of starvation.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loading grain onto a truck in February in Amritsar, in the northwestern Indian state of Punjab, near the border with Pakistan.

item.title: Meghan's Image, Battered in Britain's Tabloids, Thrives in U.S.
item.description: She has re-emerged in America as a formidable A-list celebrity and social activist. In Britain, however, Meghan remains a polarizing figure.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, at a gala for veterans in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: Portugal Bars Employers From Contacting Remote Workers Off Hours
item.description: A new law, passed on Friday and in effect this weekend, is one of the world’s boldest efforts to regulate the remote work that the pandemic forced on many in the industrialized world.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Commuters at a subway station in Lisbon last week.

item.title: Sudan Security Forces Fire on Protesters, Killing Several
item.description: At least five people were killed and several wounded as the police fired bullets and tear gas at demonstrators in Sudan’s capital, two days after the army chief signed a contentious decree.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Protesters in Port Sudan marched on Saturday against the government of Lt. Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, who has tightened his grip on Sudan since ousting the civilian prime minister.

item.title: Survivors of 2015 Paris Terrorist Attacks Testify at Trial
item.description: The trauma of the 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris was highlighted in testimony by survivors and others at a trial of 20 men accused of involvement.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial in 2015 for the victims of the terrorist attacks in Paris.

item.title: Migrants Say Belarusians Took Them to E.U. Border and Supplied Wire Cutters
item.description: Iraqi Kurds and other migrants said they were fleeing despair at home, but Belarus encouraged them, offering visas and helping them get to the border.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Elian Peltier
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kamyar and Sarhang, second and third from left, were joined by friends as they picked up their visas for Belarus on Thursday at a travel agency in Sulaimaniya, Iraq.

item.title: Urbanites in Canada Flock to Atlantic Region Amid Remote Work Shift
item.description: As housing prices soar in big cities, the country’s eastern provinces are experiencing a surge in migration. Newcomers are being welcomed, but some locals are wary.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Houses along the coastline in Bonavista, Newfoundland. Young professionals from across Canada are pouring in to the region.

item.title: Deep Underground, a Chinese Miner Discovered Poetry in the Toil
item.description: Chen Nianxi has risen to fame as a “migrant worker poet,” adding the voice of China’s often-invisible laborers to the cultural conversation.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Chen Nianxi, a miner who became a poet, in a scene from the documentary film “Iron Moon.”

item.title: Sara Duterte and Ferdinand Marcos Jr. May Join Forces in Philippines
item.description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., who hopes to succeed Rodrigo Duterte as president, said Sara Duterte would effectively be his running mate.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Jason Gutierrez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jam Sta Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son of the former dictator of the Philippines, after officially entering the presidential race last month.

item.title: Hackers Target Newfoundland’s Health Care System
item.description: The province has said little about a cyberattack that delayed or canceled medical procedures and leaked personal information.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Chris Donovan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The residents of Bonavista, like everyone in Newfoundland and Labrador, are experiencing health care disruptions.

item.title: Oklahoma Governor Puts Foe of Vaccine Mandates in Charge of National Guard
item.description: The governor, Kevin Stitt, is one of a number of Republican state officials across the country who has been fighting against President Biden’s vaccine mandates.
item.dc:creator: Ben Fenwick
item.media:description: Members of the Oklahoma National Guard were deployed to the U.S. Capitol in Washington in January.

item.title: 2 Ivory Smugglers Captured in International Operation, U.S. Says
item.description: The men were captured by relying on DNA sampling from a previously seized ivory haul, which helped experts pinpoint the location of poached elephants.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: Some of the $3.5 million worth of ivory and rhino horn seized in the operation.

item.title: Migrant Crisis in Belarus Tests Putin’s Uneasy Alliance With Lukashenko
item.description: Last year Vladimir V. Putin helped save Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s Belarusian regime. But Russia now has an ever-more-erratic ally and risks entanglement in a dangerous crisis.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in September.

item.title: In France, Kamala Harris Searches for Role on Global Stage
item.description: The vice president met with President Emmanuel Macron of France, skirting recent U.S.-French tensions, and immersed herself in issues like Libya and cybersecurity.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France and Vice President Kamala Harris in Paris on Friday.

item.title: Fears of Belarus-Poland Conflict Amid Provocative Words and Troop Moves
item.description: On both sides of the Belarus-Poland border, hyperbole and military exercises have raised fears of an armed conflict in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Belarusian Defense Ministry Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image from video released by Belarus’s Defense Ministry on Friday showing what it said were Russian paratroopers during joint military exercises near the border with Poland.

item.title: Biden and China’s Xi Will Hold Virtual Summit on Monday
item.description: The leaders of the world’s two largest economies confront tensions over trade, cyberthreats, the climate, Taiwan and human rights.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: A virtual summit between President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China has been in the works since early October.

item.title: All California Adults Can Get Booster Shots, State Says
item.description: Officials are seeking to avert a winter surge; last year, so many Covid patients died that officials were forced to deploy mobile morgues.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A pharmacist administering a booster shot at a Safeway in San Rafael, Calif., last month. California’s new policy allows all adults in the state to receive booster shots.

item.title: ‘Be Nice to Tourists’: New York’s Arts Scene Needs International Visitors
item.description: The United States now allows vaccinated international travelers into the country. It’s welcome news for arts institutions that lost revenue and cut jobs during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: About 70 percent of the tickets at the TKTS booth in Times Square are bought by tourists and roughly half of those sales are to foreign travelers.

item.title: In Border Crisis, Europe’s Unsavory Migration Deals Come Home
item.description: Europe has long paid other nations to keep refugees away from its borders. Now, Belarus wants something, too, and has brought migrants right to Europe’s door to get it.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A satellite image of migrants gathering at the Belarus-Poland border on Wednesday.

item.title: Ethiopian Civil War Sparks Rancorous Debate Over Immigration to Israel
item.description: Thousands of relatives of the remnants of Ethiopian Jewry are waiting to be airlifted to Israel. For now, the Israeli government sees no urgency.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Ethiopian immigrants arriving last year in Tel Aviv. Israel has rescued thousands of Jewish Ethiopians and their families, but questions about the eligibility of new immigrants has stirred debate.

item.title: Julian Assange Will Marry Stella Moris in London Prison
item.description: The WikiLeaks founder, who is battling extradition to the United States on espionage charges, has been granted permission to marry Stella Moris in the London prison where he has been held since 2019.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Dominic Lipinski/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Stella Moris with her children Gabriel, left, and Max in June outside Belmarsh Prison in London after a visit with Julian Assange, her partner and their father.

item.title: The Show Goes On, Even After China Tried to Shut It Down
item.description: An Italian city rejected a request from the Chinese Embassy in Rome to cancel an exhibition by Badiucao, an artist who has been described as the Chinese Banksy.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Badiucao in front of one of his works, “Carrie Lam,” a portrait of Hong Kong’s chief executive, at Santa Giulia Museum in Brescia, Italy.

item.title: Airlines Move to Curb Flow of Migrants to Belarus
item.description: Some airlines have agreed to stop taking Iraqi, Syrian and Yemeni citizens to Minsk, which the E.U. hopes will stem the flow of migrants to the bloc’s borders.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña and Carlotta Gall
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: A Turkish Airlines plane taking off from Istanbul in 2019.

item.title: China's 'Zero Covid' Efforts Come With a Cost
item.description: The Communist Party is making broad efforts to stamp out the disease entirely, but the measures come with costs.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
item.media:description: Lining up for coronavirus testing amid the emergence of local cases in Liaoning Province, China, this week.

item.title: How Does This Pandemic End?
item.description: Thinking about Covid and normalcy.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Cable car riders in San Francisco.

item.title: Netherlands Looks to Partial Lockdown as Covid Cases Rise
item.description: The Dutch lockdown does not single out those who are unvaccinated. The country is experiencing rising case numbers amid a fourth wave of infections.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Shoppers wearing face masks in Amsterdam this month.

item.title: For Some South Africans, de Klerk Missed Chances for True Reconciliation
item.description: The last white president of South Africa helped bring an end to the apartheid regime, but for many citizens, he never went far enough to disavow it. He left a video apologizing.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: F. W. de Klerk Foundation, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: F.W. de Klerk, the former president of South Africa, released a posthumous video message. “I without qualification apologize for the pain and hurt and the indignity and the damage that apartheid has done to Black, brown and Indians in South Africa.”
